Graphical abstract Hydrogenated styrene butadiene rubber (HSBR) is a high-performance elastomer with wide applications. Herein, Pd/g-C3N4 catalysts were successfully prepared via a simple chemical reduction method and applied for the selective hydrogenation of SBR. The results indicate that Pd nanoparticles are well dispersed and stably anchored on g-C3N4 due to the coordination of Pd and N, and the catalyst exhibits a superior activity with the hydrogenation degree of 95% and 100% selectivity to CC bonds of butadiene units in SBR at mild conditions. The excellent catalytic performance of Pd/g-C3N4 is attributed to: 1) the typical 2D-layered nanosheet structure can effectively eliminate the polymers diffusion effect; 2) the nitrogen-rich property of g-C3N4 itself is beneficial to anchoring Pd nanoparticles to obtain small-sized, well-dispersed and stable Pd catalyst; and 3) the π-π stacking interaction between the phenyl group in SBR and tri-s-triazine units of g-C3N4 allows SBR to be readily adsorbed on active sites. Keywords Pd/g-C3N4 Styrene-butadiene rubber Heterogeneous hydrogenation Selectivity Support 1 Introduction Styrene-butadiene rubber (SBR) is the most commonly used synthetic rubber in the world, and the excellent abrasion and aging resistance of SBR make it widely applied in tires, footwears, hose belts, wire and cable, and so on [1]. SBR is obtained by random copolymerization of styrene and butadiene monomer, the styrene units make the SBR possess excellent strength, wear, UV, weather and thermal aging resistance. However, the unsaturated carbon-carbon bonds of butadiene in the SBR make the polymer susceptible to degradation when exposed to oxygen, ozone and ultraviolet light, especially at high temperature and some other extreme conditions, limiting its application in high-tech areas [2]. But fortunately, this deficiency can be improved by the selective hydrogenation of CC of butadiene units in SBR, and after saturation, hydrogenated styrene-butadiene copolymer (HSBR) will possess high performances in tensile strength and thermoplastic elastomeric behavior, extending its potential applications in the high value-added field of medical permeable controllable membrane, polyolefin compatibilizer, and production of high-grade elastomers [3]. Chemical modification of existing polymers by hydrogenation is a relatively simple method to gain new hydrogenated products with various improved properties [4,5]. It is worth noting that the available hydrogenation methods of unsaturated CC double bonds include heterogeneous, homogeneous catalytic hydrogenation and non-catalytic hydrogenation. The non-catalytic hydrogenation is carried out by employing di-imide as the reduction agent [3,6,7], but may lead to cross-linking reaction over un-hydrogenated double bonds. The homogeneous hydrogenation catalysts reported so far include Ru(CH = CHPh)Cl(CO)(PCy3)2 [2], HRh(CO)(PPh3)3 [8], Cp2Co/BuLi [9], RhCl(PPh3)3 [10] and Ziegler-Natta [11] catalysts. However, it remains a major challenge to remove the metals from the hydrogenated products [12,13], and the remaining metals will accelerate the degradation and aging of hydrogenated products and reduce their process performance [14,15]. Therefore, the heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation of existing polymers is gaining attention to obtain high-quality HSBR rubber. Von Holleben et al., applied the commercial Pd/C as a catalyst for SBR hydrogenation [16], and the result showed that the hydrogenation degree (HD) of SBR only could reach 71 %, the lower HD might be due to the macromolecular diffusion limitations and the low accessibility to active sites. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop an efficient heterogeneous catalyst with high catalytic activity for SBR hydrogenation. Efficient and suitable support is vital for a successful rubber heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation process. It has been reported that the pore size of support should be 5 times larger than the radius of polymer in order to eliminate the effect of polymers diffusion [17,18], and the support also needs to provide space for the conformational transformation of the polymer during the reaction to enhance the accessibility to the active sites. Therefore, one solution is to design macroporous support to eliminate the diffusion effect [19–24], and another alternative way is looking for a support that can avoid the polymers diffusion limitation in pores. Recently, 2D graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) based on tri-s-triazine units as catalyst support has been widely studied in hydrogenation reaction of phenol [25,26], quinolones [27], acetylene [28], nitriles [29] and Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reaction [30] because of its low cost, high thermal and chemical stability, which shows excellent industrial prospects [31]. However. g-C3N4 as catalyst support for the heterogeneous hydrogenation of polymer macromolecules remains untouched, to the best of our knowledge. Herein, a series of Pd/g-C3N4 catalysts with varying Pd contents was prepared by a simple chemical reduction method and applied in SBR heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation for the first time. The influence of Pd active sites, solvent effect and support properties on the SBR hydrogenation were comprehensively explored. Pd/g-C3N4 catalyst exhibited a significantly improved catalytic activity with a high HD to CC bonds of butadiene units under mild reaction conditions with cyclohexane as solvent, superior to SiO2 or C as catalyst support. Most importantly, the reaction mechanism and the advantages of g-C3N4 for SBR hydrogenation was revealed for the first time, paving the way on the rational design and controllable synthesis efficient catalysts for macromolecular heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of Pd/g-C3N4 catalyst The g-C3N4 support was synthesized by thermal polymerization of urea [32]. Briefly, 20 g of well ground urea was taken into an alumina crucible with a cover, which was heated to 550 °C at a rate of 2 °C min−1 in a muffle furnace for 4 h. The obtained yellow powder was gathered without further treatment. Pd/g-C3N4 catalysts with a Pd loading of 0.5–1.5 wt. % were prepared using chemical reduction method [33]. Typically, 1.0 g prepared g-C3N4 was dispersed into 100 mL deionized water with sonication until it is evenly dispersed. Then, a solution of an appropriate amount of palladium chloride dissolved into 28 mL of HCl (1 mol/L) was added slowly into the above suspension under stirring at 30 °C for 0.5 h, then NaOH (1 mol/L) solution was added to adjust the pH of the mixture solution to 10. Finally, an excess solution of NaBH4 (1 mol/L, freshly prepared) was added dropwise with the molar ratio of Pd2+: NaBH4 = 1:5 under stirring vigorously to reduce Pd(II) to Pd(0), and the color of the mixture changed quickly from light yellow to grayish brown. After 3 h, the gray-brown product was separated by filtration, washed three times with deionized water and ethanol respectively, and vacuum dried overnight at 60 °C. Depending on the ratio of m(Pd):m(g-C3N4) = 0.5%, 1.0% and 1.5%, the catalysts were labeled as Pd0.5/g-C3N4, Pd1.0/g-C3N4 and Pd1.5/g-C3N4, respectively. 2.2 Synthesis of Pd/SiO2 and Pd/N-SiO2 catalyst For comparison, the Pd/C (1.0 wt %) catalyst was purchased from Shaanxi Rock New Materials Co., Ltd. The Pd/SiO2 (1.0 wt %) catalyst was synthesized by the incipient wetness impregnation. Firstly, 0.0173 g of palladium chloride solution dissolved in HCl (1 mol/L) was added dropwise into SiO2 support (purchased from Fujian Yuchenghuanbao Co., Ltd.), which was dried at room temperature for 12 h. The obtained solid was calcined at 300 °C for 4 h in muffle furnace. After cooling to room temperature, the Pd2+/SiO2 solid was reduced under H2 atmosphere at 140 °C for 2 h to prepare Pd/SiO2 catalyst. To further investigate the effects of support itself to eliminate nitrogen-rich factors, the Pd/N-SiO2 catalyst was prepared. The synthesis of N-SiO2 support was as follows: 1.0 g SiO2 was dispersed into 20 mL toluene with stirring until it is evenly dispersed. Then a solution of 1.0 mmol N-[3-(trimethoxy silyl) propyl]ethylenediamine (EDAS) dissolved into 10 mL toluene was added into above suspension. The obtained suspension was stirred for 10 min at room temperature and stirred slowly at 80 °C for 24 h. The product was separated by centrifugation, washed three times with toluene. The resulting solid was dispersed in ethanol and heated to 60 °C for 8 h, and centrifuged, dried at 100 °C. Finally, the Pd/N-SiO2 (1.0 wt %) catalyst was also prepared by the IM method. 2.3 SBR hydrogenation reaction The SBR hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a 500 mL high-pressure autoclave reactor. The SBR copolymer (1.0 g) dissolved in cyclohexane (80 g) and Pd/g-C3N4 (1.0 g) was placed into the reactor, and then flushed by bubbling nitrogen gas to replace air for 2 min at room temperature. After that, the reactor was heated to 60 °C, and the H2 was introduced to the reactor and maintained at 1.0 MPa. The stirring speed was 800 rpm/min, and the reaction time for SBR hydrogenation was 2.5 h. Finally, the hydrogenated SBR solution was centrifuged to separate the catalyst, HSBR was obtained by precipitating the polymer in ethanol and then dried in an oven at 80 °C for 10 h. The schematic diagram of SBR is illustrated in Scheme 1 . The HD of HSBR was calculated by Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and further confirmed by proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR). The detailed calculations are presented in the Supporting Information. 2.4 Solvent effect of SBR hydrogenation reaction In order to investigate the effect of different solvents on SBR hydrogenation, SBR hydrogenation reactions on six different solvents of toluene, benzene, n-heptane, n-octane, cyclohexane and a mixed solvent of toluene and n-octane were carried out. The reaction conditions were set as follows: 1.0 g SBR dissolved into 80 g solvent, 1.0 g Pd/g-C3N4 (1.0 wt%), H2 pressure of 1.0 MPa, 60 °C for 2.5 h. 2.5 Adsorption measurement of SBR The adsorption experiments of SBR on g-C3N4, SiO2, N-SiO2, Pd/g-C3N4, Pd/SiO2, Pd/N-SiO2 and Pd/C were studied using a similar way with the hydrogenation reaction conditions. Typically, SBR (1.0 g) dissolved in cyclohexane (80 g) was added into the beaker, then the samples (1.0 g) was added when the temperature reached to 60 °C. At the same time, started sampling at a certain interval. After the samples solution were diluted with cyclohexane, the concentration of the samples solution was characterized by Ultraviolet-visible spectra (UV–vis). Firstly, the absorbance at 261.5 nm of a series known concentrations of SBR solutions were measured by UV–vis, then the calibration curve between concentrations (mg/mL) and absorbance (A) was obtained. Thus, the SBR solutions of unknown concentration can be obtained by the calibration curve. The adsorption percentage (XAd) was evaluated using Eq. (1): (1) XAd = C SBR 0 - C SBR C SBR 0 where the C S B R 0  = 9.85 mg/mL is the initial concentration of SBR solution, and the CSBR is the saturated concentration. 2.6 Characterizations Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were performed on a Philips Tecnai G2 F20 microscope operating at 200 kV. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was conducted on S-4800 (Hitachi, Japan). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were recorded on a KYOWAGLAS-XA H-12 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 30 mA with the scanning angle ranged from 10° to 80° of 2θ. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were conducted by Nicolet is50 spectrophotometer. For each spectrum, 32 scans were collected in the range of wave numbers of 4000-650 cm−1. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were performed at 77 K on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on an Escalab 250Xi system, and the binding energies were calibrated using a C 1s binding energy of 284.8 eV. The dispersion of Pd NPs was obtained by CO chemisorption on Micromeritics:2920II. The ultraviolet-visible spectra (UV–vis) were employed to examine the absorbance of the SBR solution in adsorption experiment of SBR on LAMBDA800 PE/LAMBDA800 PE. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopic analysis (NMR) was employed to determine the HD of HSBR samples on a Bruker Ascend™ 400, using CDCl3 as the solvent and TMS as internal standards. Dilute solution viscosity measurement was used to indirectly determine the crosslinking density of the HSBR samples. The viscosity of dilute polymer solutions (0.1250 ± 0.0005 g of SBR or HSBR per 25 mL of toluene) was measured at 30 °C by using an Ubbelohde capillary viscometer (0.5-0.6 cm). If crosslinking occurs in the polymer, the relative viscosity (ηrel) of the polymer solution will change significantly. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphology of Pd/g-C3N4 catalyst The SEM images of g-C3N4 support and Pd/g-C3N4 catalysts with different Pd loading amounts are shown in Figure S1. It is clear that the g-C3N4 support displays a typical layered nanostructure with certain aggregation. The morphology is kept well after the deposition of Pd particles (Figure S1b, c, and d). The TEM images of g-C3N4 and Pd/g-C3N4 catalysts are exhibited in Fig. 1 , respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 1a, the g-C3N4 displays a typical graphite-like morphology [34]. After the introduction of Pd NPs (Fig. 1b, c, and d), it is clear that Pd NPs are uniformly dispersed on the surface of g-C3N4 nanostructure accompanied with the preservation of the platelet-like structure. The three prepared catalysts Pd/g-C3N4 exhibited the same mean size of 2.9 nm with a narrow distribution on the basis of a count of more than 100 individual nanoparticles via TEM analysis. The average size of Pd NPs could be calculated using Eq. (2) [35]: (2) ds ¯ = Σ ni d i 3 Σ ni d i 2 where n i is the number of Pd NPs with diameter of d i , and the number ( ∑ n i ) is larger than 100. According to the procedures described by Mahata and Vishwanathan [36] and Anderson [37], the dispersion (D) of Pd NPs can be roughly calculated by the following equation: (3) D ( Pd dispersion ) = 1.12 d ( mean diameter of Pd nanoparticles, nm ) The D value of the three catalysts Pd/g-C3N4 based on the mean size is determined to be 39%, suggesting that the Pd/g-C3N4 has a large number of active sites. The Pd dispersions obtained from CO chemisorption are 75%, 65% and 48% for Pd0.5/g-C3N4, Pd1.0/g-C3N4 and Pd1.5/g-C3N4, respectively. The high-dispersion of three catalysts with different Pd loading amount is mainly due to that the nitrogen-rich property of the g-C3N4 is beneficial to anchoring Pd nanoparticles to obtain well-dispersed Pd catalyst. Fig. 2 A displays the XRD patters of g-C3N4 and prepared catalysts Pd/g-C3N4, respectively. The most intense diffraction peak appeared at 27.6° that indexed as (002) in g-C3N4, which can be attributed to the typical interlayer-stacking peak. The other weak characteristic peak at 13.6° that indexed as (100) in g-C3N4 may be assigned to the in-plane tri-s-triazine structural packing motifs between nitride pores [38]. After the introduction of Pd NPs, the intensity of characteristic peaks at 27.6° is significantly reduced compared with g-C3N4 support, which may be ascribed to the electrostatic attraction between the negative charges on the sheet of g-C3N4 and the Pd2+. The XRD patterns of Pd/g-C3N4 (b, c, and d in Fig. 2A) have no noticeable characteristic diffraction peaks belongs to Pd NPs, revealing that the particle sizes of Pd NPs are below the detection limit of XRD analysis. The FT-IR spectra of the g-C3N4 and Pd/g-C3N4 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2B. For g-C3N4, the significant bands at 810 cm−1 and 886 cm−1 can be attributed to the ring-sextant out-of-plane skeletal bending vibration of tri-s-triazine cycles units [31,38]. The intense bands located between 1650-1000 cm−1 observed in g-C3N4 are due to the typical stretching vibration modes of the CN and CN in tri-s-triazine rings. The broad bands in the 3500-2800 cm−1 region belong to the characteristic peak of NH stretching vibration modes. It is worth noting that no apparent change of these main characteristic bands in the spectra of the Pd/g-C3N4 (b, c, d in Fig. 2B) can be observed, suggesting that there is no covalently coupled interaction between the graphitic structure of g-C3N4 and Pd NPs in the catalysts. Figure S2 illustrates the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of samples. As clearly seen from Figure S2a, all samples show distinct IV isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops. The pore size distribution curves are recorded in the range of 3–80 nm (Figure S2b). The formed pores are due to the stacking of g-C3N4 nanosheets. The Pd/g-C3N4 catalysts exhibit almost the same isotherm shape and pore diameter compared to g-C3N4, indicating that the plane structure of the support is well maintained after the loading of Pd NPs [39]. The values of structure parameters are listed in Table 1 . The XPS analysis is performed to determine the surface elemental composition. The XPS survey spectrums of g-C3N4 and three catalysts Pd/g-C3N4 are shown in Figure S3, indicating the coexistence of C, N and O in g-C3N4 and C, N, O, Pd after deposition of Pd NPs. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the peaks at 284.80 eV and 288.01 eV correspond to the graphitic carbon and sp2 N-C = N, respectively. It is clear that there are two doublets in the spectrum of Pd 3d, the peaks at 335.05 eV and 340.32 eV are assigned to Pd0 3d3/2 and Pd0 3d5/2, the peaks at 337.27 eV and 342.87 eV belong to the Pd2+ 3d5/2 and Pd2+ 3d3/2 [40], the existence of Pd2+ may be the result of incomplete reduction of PdCl2 during the preparation or the partial oxidation of Pd0 at the ambient conditions. Based on the peak areas, the ratio of Pd0/(Pd2++Pd0) is estimated to be 51.66%, 64.76% and 56.28% for Pd0.5/g-C3N4, Pd1.0/g-C3N4, and Pd1.5/g-C3N4, respectively. It is well known that the higher ratio of Pd0 is beneficial to better catalytic activity [41–43]. As shown in Fig. 3b, the N 1s spectrum of the g-C3N4 can be deconvoluted into three peaks at binding energies of 398.50, 399.99 and 401.11 eV, which can be attributed to the pyridine nitrogen, pyrrolic N and graphitic nitrogen, respectively. It is intriguing to find that the N 1s spectrum has a positive shift when Pd NPs loaded on g-C3N4, which may be ascribed to the fact that the N atoms of g-C3N4 provide electrons to Pd NPs [46]. It was reported that pyridinic N and graphitic N sites are closely related to the anchoring of metal NPs [44,45]. According to Fig. 3b and Table 2 , it can be seen that the pyridinic N existed dominantly in g-C3N4, which is favorable to the dispersion and anchoring of Pd NPs. Table 2 includes the XPS data of pyridinic N, Pd0 3d5/2 and Pd0 3d3/2 binding energies and for the catalysts before and after deposition of Pd NPs. 3.2 Catalytic performance on hydrogenation of SBR The FT-IR spectra of the different HD of HSBR products and SBR are shown in Fig. 4 . The peaks at 2924 and 2855 cm−1 in all samples (Fig. 4A) are ascribed to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration absorption peak of −CH2-. Other obvious peaks at 1601, 1494, and 1451 cm−1 (Fig. 4B) can be ascribed to the skeleton vibration of aromatic ring, stretching vibration of double bonds of aromatic ring and deformation of aromatic ring, respectively. The peaks at 760 and 700 cm−1 correspond to the phenyl group of styrene units [11]. The peak at 910 cm−1 is attributed to vinyl CHCH2 and the peak at 970 cm−1 in SBR is assigned to 1,4- trans units. It can be observed from the IR spectrum of SBR that the characteristic peak intensity of 1,4 CHCH is much stronger than 1,2 −CH = CH2, indicating that the 1,4 CHCH unit exists dominantly in SBR structure. A new peak at 723 cm−1 can be observed in HSBR which is ascribed to -(CH2)n- group (n>4) resulting from the hydrogenation of CC bonds in butadiene units. It should be noted that the characteristic peak at 910 cm−1 is almost disappeared in all HSBR samples suggesting the nearly complete hydrogenation of vinyl CHCH2 bonds. Based on the calculation, the HD of HSBR can reach 88% with HD1,2-C=C of 95 % and HD1,4-C=C of 86% when the Pd loading amount is 0.5%. Comparatively, the HD is increased significantly to 95% with HD1,2-C=C of 98% and HD1,4-C=C of 94% at a Pd loading of 1.0%. However, the HD is no longer increased when the Pd loading is further increased to 1.5%. It should be noted that the characteristic peaks for phenyl group at 1601, 1494, 1451, 760 and 700 cm−1 are retained and no new peaks in the range of 820-900 cm−1 assigned to cyclohexyl group can be found indicating that the phenyl group is not hydrogenated and the selectivity to CC of butadiene units is 100%. The influence of reaction parameters (temperature and pressure) on SBR hydrogenation was further investigated by using Pd1.0/g-C3N4 as catalyst and the results are shown in Figure S4. It is clear that the reaction temperature can affect the hydrogenation activity, and the HD is increased from 84 % to 95 % when the temperature is raised from 30 °C to 60 °C but it is no longer increased when further increasing the temperature to 90 °C. The hydrogen pressure has almost no effect on the reaction, probably because H2 is excessive throughout the investigation range. The NMR is used to analyze the microstructure of polymer and further confirm the HD of HSBR produced by different loading of Pd/g-C3N4. Fig. 5 shows the representative NMR spectra of the SBR and HSBR polymers. For SBR, the olefinic protons appear in the region of 4.6–5.8 ppm. The peak at 0.89 ppm belongs to CH3 C, the peak at 1.28 ppm is ascribed to CH3, the peak at 1.58 ppm is assigned to CH2 CH2 and the peak at 2.03 ppm is classified as CH2 of CH2 CHCHCH2 . With the progress in hydrogenation, it is observed that the olefinic peak area around 4.6–5.8 ppm decreases considerably and almost disappear. It is clear that the intensity of the peak at δ = 1.28 ppm increases gradually with the improvement of HD, which is formed by the hydrogenation of CC of butadiene units and provides spectroscopic evidence for SBR hydrogenation [6]. There is no change in the intensity of aromatic peaks in the region of 6.8–7.2 ppm, and no new peak appears at 1.43 ppm corresponds to cyclohexane reflecting the stability of aromatic ring towards Pd/g-C3N4, further confirming the high selectivity to CC of butadiene units. The HD for HSBR by different loading of Pd/g-C3N4 are calculated to 91%, 96% and 96%, which in good agreement with the FTIR result. 3.3 Crosslinking determination It is possible to observe indirectly whether the crosslinking occurs in the hydrogenated polymer of SBR [2]. The HSBR polymer solutions dissolved in toluene are still very clear, and there is no observable gel formed after the SBR hydrogenation. Dilute solution viscosity measurement was applied to calculate the relative viscosity ηrel, the results are shown in Table S1. Compared with SBR, the ηrel of HSBR did not change significantly, indicating that the HSBR polymer after SBR hydrogenation over various catalysts did not crosslink, it also means that the high-quality HSBR polymers can be obtained by heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation of SBR over Pd/g-C3N4. 3.4 Solvent effect on SBR hydrogenation The solvent effect has been an important issue for hydrogenation of polymers, so the effect of different solvents on the heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation of SBR was further carried out. The HD results of SBR among different solvents are shown in Table 3 , and the FTIR images are shown in Figure S5. It is clear that the cyclohexane solvent is the best for SBR catalytic system, which exhibits a higher HD of 95%. A possible explanation is the principle of similar solubility parameters σ. The solubility parameter of SBR is 8.33, which is very close to that of cyclohexane. The HD of HSBR is lower when toluene and benzene as solvent, although the σ of toluene is closer to SBR than n-heptane and n-octane. It is worth noting that the HD of HSBR can reach up to 93% when the mixed solvent of n-octane and toluene was used as solvent. This can be explained by the principle of similar polarity. The SBR is a non-polar polymer, and the polarity of toluene and benzene is much greater than the n-heptane, n-octane and cyclohexane, thus the SBR can be better dissolved in non-polar solvents. In addition, the competitive adsorption between benzene/toluene and SBR on the catalyst may also result in lower HD. 3.5 Support effect on SBR hydrogenation Favorable support is essential for a successful catalytic hydrogenation process. In order to investigate the vital effect of support itself on the dispersion of Pd active sites and catalytic activity for the SBR heterogeneous hydrogenation reaction, the Pd/C, Pd/SiO2 and Pd/N-SiO2 catalysts with the identical Pd loading amount of 1.0% were compared with Pd/g-C3N4 under the same reaction conditions. Fig. 6 A shows the XRD patters of SiO2 (a), Pd/SiO2 (c) and Pd/N-SiO2 (b) catalysts. It is clear that the wide peak at 2θ = 22.1° is ascribed to the typical amorphous silica structure. The XRD image of Pd/N-SiO2 has no noticeable characteristic peaks belongs to Pd nanoparticles, indicating that the Pd NPs are quite small and well dispersed on N-SiO2 support. However, four weak diffraction peaks at 2θ = 40.2, 46.6, 68.1 and 81.8° assigned to (111), (200), (220), (311) of Pd crystallites [21] can be observed for Pd/SiO2, suggesting the large size of Pd NPs aggregating on pure silica support. The XRD pattern of commercial Pd/C is shown in Fig. 6B. The diffraction peaks appeared at 24.1°, and 43.4° are attributed to the (002) and (101) reflections of the amorphous carbon structure. The weak peak at 40.3° corresponds to the (111) reflection of Pd NPs. The TEM images of Pd/C and Pd NPs over N-modified and unmodified SiO2 support are performed and presented in Fig. 7 . Pd/N-SiO2 (Fig. 7a) clearly exhibits that the Pd particles are evenly distributed on the surface of N-SiO2 support without aggregation, the average size of the nanoparticles is about 2.9 nm, which is close to the value of Pd/g-C3N4 catalyst. However, the Pd/SiO2 (Fig. 7b) catalyst shows much larger Pd NPs size of 5.7 nm with severe aggregation, and the grain size of Pd/C (Fig. 7c) is about 3.7 nm, indicating that the strong interactions between Pd NPs and N atoms are beneficial to the formation of small-sized Pd NPs and stabilize the dispersion of Pd NPs over support. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of Pd/C, Pd/SiO2 and Pd/N-SiO2 are shown in Figure S6 and the values of structure parameters are listed in Table S2. In Figure S5A, the Pd/C catalyst shows distinct IV isotherms with H4-type hysteresis loops, indicating the coexistence of micropores and mesopores. It is further proved that the mesopores account for the most in Pd/C catalyst (Figure S5B). It can be found (Figure S5C) that both the Pd/SiO2 and Pd/N-SiO2 display a distinct IV isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of mesopores in two samples. The FTIR images and HD of SBR over different catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . The catalytic results show that the commercial Pd/C catalyst exhibits a lower HD of 68%, mainly due to the SBR macromolecular diffusion limitations and low accessibility to active sites. The HD of HSBR is only 56% when the pure SiO2 as support, may be the result that the weak interaction between Pd and SiO2 support, resulting in the larger Pd particles and fewer active sites, which is consistent with the results of XRD and TEM. In contrast, the HD increases to 73% after the SiO2 support is functionalized by amino groups, indicating that amino modification of support is beneficial to disperse and stabilize Pd NPs [47,48]. While the HD of HSBR can reach 95% when g-C3N4 as the support, confirming further that the 2D layered nanosheet structure can effectively eliminate the polymers diffusion effect in the pores and the nitrogen-rich property of the support itself is beneficial to anchoring Pd nanoparticles to obtain the small-sized, well-dispersed and stable Pd catalyst. 3.6 Mechanism In order to further demonstrate that the g-C3N4 is superior to other support for SBR hydrogenation, the adsorption experiments of SBR on g-C3N4, SiO2, N-SiO2 and Pd/g-C3N4, Pd/SiO2, Pd/N-SiO2, Pd/C were studied, respectively. The calibration curve between concentrations (mg/mL) and absorbance (A) is shown in Figure S7. As shown in Table 4 , it is worth noting that the g-C3N4 has a maximum of XAd compared with SiO2 or C as support. After introduction of Pd NPs, the XAd follows the order: Pd/g-C3N4 > Pd/N-SiO2 > Pd/C > Pd/SiO2, which is consistent with hydrogenation results. The superior adsorption performance of SBR on g-C3N4 and Pd/g-C3N4 mainly can be attributed to the π-π stacking interaction [38] between the phenyl group of SBR polymers and tri-s-triazine units of g-C3N4. The π-π stacking interaction promotes SBR polymer macromolecule rapidly access to the Pd actives sites, resulting in high HD. In summary, the g-C3N4 support plays a vital effect in heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation of SBR. Firstly, the typical 2D layered nanosheet structure of g-C3N4 support with graphitic planes can completely avoid the diffusion limitations in pores of SBR polymer macromolecules. Secondly, the g-C3N4 support is an N-rich material, which is beneficial to disperse and stabilize the Pd NPs. Thirdly, the g-C3N4 is constructed from tri-s-triazine units with π electron conjugation, the π-π stacking interaction between phenyl group of SBR polymer and tri-s-triazine units of g-C3N4 facilitates the adsorption of SBR molecules on catalyst and promotes the contact of CC of butadiene units with Pd active sites. Accordingly, the mechanism of the heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation of SBR catalyzed by Pd/g-C3N4 is illustrated in Scheme 2 . H2 molecule is first adsorbed on the Pd active sites and then dissociated, which can be easily reacted with the unsaturated CC of butadiene units of SBR molecules simultaneously absorbed on Pd active sites. The π-π stacking interaction between the phenyl group of SBR polymer and the tri-s-triazine units of g-C3N4 promotes the SBR to be quickly adsorbed on the g-C3N4 support, and further allow the SBR quickly access to the Pd active sites, resulting in an excellent catalytic performance. Finally, the valuable HSBR polymer is obtained, which shows excellent industrial prospects. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have demonstrated a simple and efficient chemical reduction method for the synthesis of Pd/g-C3N4 catalysts. The catalysts show superior catalytic activity and high selectivity in SBR heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation reaction at a mild condition. As a result, the HD of HSBR can reach 95% when the loading amount of Pd NPs is only 1.0%. Compared with commercial catalysts Pd/C and Pd/SiO2, the improved catalytic activity of Pd/g-C3N4 can be ascribed to the unique nanostructure of g-C3N4, including the 2D layered structure can avoid the diffusion limitation in pores of SBR, the characteristic of N-rich is beneficial to dispersion of Pd NPs and formation of small-sized Pd active sites, and the π-π stacking interaction between the phenyl group of the SBR polymer and the tri-s-triazine ring unit of g-C3N4 can help in improving the catalytic activity as the SBR can be easily absorbed on the Pd active sites. The unique nanostructure endowed the g-C3N4 as potential catalyst support for polymer macromolecule heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogenated styrene butadiene rubber (HSBR) is a high-performance elastomer with wide applications. Herein, Pd/g-C3N4 catalysts were successfully prepared via a simple chemical reduction method and applied for the selective hydrogenation of SBR. The results indicate that Pd nanoparticles are well dispersed and stably anchored on g-C3N4 due to the coordination of Pd and N, and the catalyst exhibits a superior activity with the hydrogenation degree of 95% and 100% selectivity to CC bonds of butadiene units in SBR at mild conditions. The excellent catalytic performance of Pd/g-C3N4 is attributed to: 1) the typical 2D-layered nanosheet structure can effectively eliminate the polymers diffusion effect; 2) the nitrogen-rich property of g-C3N4 itself is beneficial to anchoring Pd nanoparticles to obtain small-sized, well-dispersed and stable Pd catalyst; and 3) the π-π stacking interaction between the phenyl group in SBR and tri-s-triazine units of g-C3N4 allows SBR to be readily adsorbed on active sites.
coredata.dc:title: Selectively catalytic hydrogenation of styrene-butadiene rubber over Pd/g-C3N4 catalyst
